case_name: Messrs George Restaurant and Stores v. Union of India

facts.text: Petition No. 56 of 1962 filed under Article 32 of the Constitution for enforcement of Fundamental Rights.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Petition No. 56 of 1962.  Under Article 32 of the Constitution of India for the enforcement of Fundamental Rights .

facts.text: Judgment delivered by Sinha, C.J. on November 9, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: 1962. November 9. The judgment of the Court was delivered by SINHA, C. J This petition, under Art. 32 of the Constitution,

facts.text: Petitioners are 5 citizens of India carrying on business of running a restaurant and general stores named Messrs George Restaurant and Stores at 20, Apollo Street, Fort, Bombay-1, since September 1958.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners, 5 in number, are citizens of India and are carrying on business of running a restaurant and general stores under the name and style of Messrs George Restaurant and Stores at 20, Appollo Street, Fort, Bombay-1, since September, 1958.

facts.text: Petitioners run the business as a partnership firm registered under the Indian Partnership Act.

anchor.surface_text: They are. running this business as a partnership firm, registered under the Indian Partnership Act. The firm employs 43 persons, including companyks, waiters, tea-makers, bill clerks and two store-clerks.

facts.text: The firm employs 43 persons, including cooks, waiters, tea-makers, bill clerks and two store-clerks.

anchor.surface_text: The firm employs 43 persons, including companyks, waiters, tea-makers, bill clerks and two store-clerks. Besides paying salary to their employees, the petitioners give them free food and other personal allowances,

facts.text: Petitioners pay salary to employees and give free food and other personal allowances.

anchor.surface_text: Besides paying salary to their employees, the petitioners give them free food and other personal allowances, which it is number necessary to set out in detail.

facts.text: Central Government issued Notification No. G.S.R. 704 dated May 16, 1961 under s.1(3)(b) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: In exercise of the powers companyferred by s. 1 3  b  of the Act, the General Government issued the numberification No. G.S.R. 704, dated May 16, 1961, in the following terms S.R. 704--In exercise of the ,powers company- ferred by Clause  b  of sub-section 3 of Section 1 of the Employees Provident Fund Act,

facts.text: Notification G.S.R. 704 directs that with effect from June 30, 1961, the Act applies to hotels and restaurants employing 20 or more persons.

anchor.surface_text: the Central Government hereby directs that. with effect from June 30, 1961, the said Act shall apply. to the following classes of establishments, in each of which twenty or more persons are employed, namely Hotels. ii. Restaurants.

facts.text: As a result of Notification G.S.R. 704, the Act extends to hotels and restaurants including the one run by petitioners.

anchor.surface_text: As a result of the numberification aforesaid, the operation of the Act has been extended to hotels and restaurants, including the one run by the petitioners.

facts.text: Central Government issued Notification S.R. 783 under s.5 read with s.7(1) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: Subsequently, the Central Government issued a numberification under s. 5, read with s. 7 1 , of the Act, the relevant portions of which are in these terms S.R. 783.-In exercise 1 of the powers company- ferred by section 5 read with subsection  1  of section 7, of the Employees Provident Funds Act,

facts.text: Notification S.R. 783 makes the Employees Provident Funds Third Amendment Scheme, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: This Scheme may be called the Employees Provident Funds  Third Amendment  Scheme, 1961. In the Employees Provident Fund Scheme, 1952, in clause  b  of sub-paragraph.  3  of paragraph 1,

facts.text: The Third Amendment Scheme, 1961 inserts provisions for hotels and restaurants covered by G.S.R. 704 dated May 16, 1961 coming into force on June 30, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: as respects hotels and, restaurants Covered by the numberification of the,Government of India in the Ministry of Labour and Employment No. G.S.R. 704 dated May 16, 1961 companye into force on the 30th day of June 1961

facts.text: Petitioners challenge constitutionality of the scheme and sections of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners challenge the companystitutionality of the scheme aforesaid, and the section of the Act in pursuance of which it was brought into existence.

facts.text: Petitioners pray for writ quashing the notifications and mandamus not to apply the scheme.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners pray for a writ or order or direction quashing the said numberifica- tions and for issue of a mandamus to the respondents number to apply the said scheme to the petitioners establishment.

facts.text: Employees Provident Funds Act is Act 19 of 1952.

anchor.surface_text: challenges the vires of certain provisions of the Employees Provident Funds Act  19 of 1952  which hereinafter will be referred to as the Act,

facts.text: Respondents are Union of India and Regional Provident Fund Commissioner.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents to this petition I are the Union of India and the Regional Provident Fund Commissioner.

facts.text: Act applies to factories engaged in Schedule I industries employing 20 or more persons.

anchor.surface_text: The Act applies to every establishment which is a factory engaged in any industry specified in schedule 1 and in which 20 or more persons are employed,

facts.text: Central Government may notify other establishments employing 20 or more persons.

anchor.surface_text: and to any other establishment employing 20 or more persons or class of such establishments which is Central Government may by numberification in the Official Gazette, specify in this behalf.

facts.text: Employee defined in s.2(f) as any person employed for wages in any kind of work, manual or otherwise.

anchor.surface_text: Employee has been defined in S. 2 f  as follows employee means any person who is employed for wages in any kind of work, manual or otherwise, in or in companynection with the work of an establishment,

facts.text: Court holds there is no substance in petitioners' contentions challenging s.1(3)(b), applicability to salaried employees, and discrimination under Art.14.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion there is numbersubstance in any one of these companytentions.

facts.text: Act intended to institute provident funds for benefit of employees in factories and other establishments.

anchor.surface_text: The whole Act is directed to institute provident funds for the benefit, of employees in factories and other establishments, as the preamble indicates.

facts.text: s.16 exempts certain cooperative societies and newly set up establishments for 3 or 5 years.

anchor.surface_text: By s. 16 it is provided that the Act shall number apply to any establishment registered under the Co-operative Societies Act of 1912, or to any other establishment employing 50 or more persons or 20 or more but less than 50 persons until the expiry of 3 years in the case of the former and 5 years in the case of the latter,
Under Article 32 of the Constitution of India for the enforcement of Fundamental Rights . C. Chatterji, S. K. Kapur and K. K. Jain, for the Petitioners.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Act's policy for provident funds in preamble; ss.16 and 17 provide guidance via exemptions only for equal/superior benefits; presumption against abuse of discretion; supported by precedents like Eduard Mills and Vasantal Maganbhai

holdings.text: It cannot be asserted that the powers entrusted to the Central Government to bring within the purview of the Act such establishments or class of establishments as the Government may by notification in the Official Gazette specify is uncontrolled and uncanalised

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion there is nosubstance in any one of these contentions. It cannot be asserted that the powers entrusted to the Central Government to bring within the purview of the Act such establishments or class of establishments as the Government may by notification in the Official Gazette specify is uncontrolled and uncanalised. The whole Act is directed to institute provident funds for the benefit, of employees in factories and other establishments, as the preamble indicates.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Legislature indicated policy to extend provident funds to factories and other establishments employing 20+ persons; discretion guided by relevant information available to government

holdings.text: It is manifest that there is no force in this contention [that the Act was intended to apply only to wage earners not salaried employees]
holdings.reasoning_summary: No definition of 'wages' but 'basic wages' broadly includes all emoluments earned on duty/leave paid in cash; salary and wages both recompense for labour, no statutory distinction; covers skilled/unskilled

holdings.text: there is absolutely no reason for complaint that the petitioners establishment of that class has been chosen for hostile discrimination
